Introduction

Mastoiditis is an infection and inflammation of the mastoid air cells, typically occurring as a complication of acute otitis media (AOM) (

figure 1
).  Mastoiditis can lead to local and systemic complications if not promptly recognized and managed.  Although antibiotic therapy has reduced the incidence of mastoiditis, it remains a potential complication of middle ear infections.

Pathophysiology



The mastoid is a part of the temporal bone; mastoiditis occurs when pathogens from the middle ear spread into the mastoid air cells, leading to inflammation, bony destruction, and potential abscess formation.  The mastoid air cells are in continuity with the middle ear, allowing the spread of infection.  The infection may progress beyond the mastoid, causing subperiosteal abscesses, venous sinus thrombosis, or other intracranial complications.



As with AOM, the most common causative organisms include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and, less commonly, Haemophilus influenzae and Staphylococcus aureus.  Pseudomonas aeruginosa is occasionally implicated, especially in patients with recurrent infections or recent antibiotic use.

Risk factors



Mastoiditis, like AOM, is most commonly seen in children age â‰¤2.  Additional risk factors include recent or recurrent AOM and inadequate or delayed antibiotic treatment of AOM.  In some patients, mastoiditis can occur with the first episode.

Pathology



Histopathologic findings include neutrophilic infiltration, osteoclastic bone resorption, and destruction of trabecular bone.  In chronic cases, granulation tissue formation and fibrosis may be observed.  Abscess formation within the mastoid air cells is common in advanced disease.

Clinical presentation



Patients are typically age â‰¤2 and often present with fever and ear pain, as seen in AOM.  Young infants with AOM may have nonspecific signs and symptoms of irritability, poor sleep, and decreased appetite.  In addition to ear pain, patients usually have:



  • Postauricular erythema and tenderness.
  • Protrusion of the outer ear.


Infection of the mastoid produces postauricular erythema and tender swelling, causing outward and/or vertical displacement of the auricle (eg, protrusion) (

figure 2
).  The tympanic membrane often shows evidence of AOM (eg, erythema, bulging, perforation), although it may not be visible if swelling of the external auditory canal is present.  About half of patients develop otorrhea.

Diagnosis



Acute mastoiditis is often diagnosed clinically.  A complete blood count can show nonspecific findings for infection, including a leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance, elevated C-reactive protein, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.  Culture of the middle ear fluid usually identifies the pathogen and antibiotic susceptibility.



Imaging is indicated if the diagnosis is unclear, there is suspicion for complications (eg, meningitis, neurologic deficits), the child appears toxic, or the condition does not respond to initial treatment.  In these cases, a CT scan, which is usually best for visualizing the temporal bone, shows destruction of the bony septa in the mastoid air cells, confirming the diagnosis of acute coalescent mastoiditis.  If an intracranial complication is suspected, MRI of the brain with contrast may also be indicated.

Differential diagnosis



  • Cholesteatoma (
    figure 3
    ):  Can develop in patients with recurrent AOM.  However, cholesteatoma typically presents with recurrent painless otorrhea.  Examination shows a pearly white mass or a retraction pocket in the superior portion of the tympanic membrane.
  • Necrotizing (malignant) otitis externa:  Can present with severe ear pain and a swollen external auditory canal.  However, it typically occurs in elderly patients with diabetes mellitus, and examination characteristically shows granulation tissue at the bony cartilaginous junction.  It is not typically a complication of AOM.
  • Parotitis:  Can present with fever and painful swelling around the ear; however, both preauricular and postauricular swelling are present.  It typically occurs in elderly postoperative patients rather than in young children.
  • Perichondritis:  Can present with a painful, erythematous ear due to infection of the perichondrium.  However, erythema and tenderness are limited to the cartilaginous portions of the ear; the mastoid bone is not affected.
  • Suppurative labyrinthitis:  Can occur as a complication of AOM due to the spread of infection to the bony labyrinth of the inner ear.  In addition to the symptoms of fever and otalgia due to AOM, patients with suppurative labyrinthitis typically have severe vertigo with nystagmus, nausea and vomiting, and significant hearing loss.

Management



The treatment of mastoiditis requires empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy with activity against common upper respiratory pathogens (eg, S pneumoniae), as well as S pyogenes and S aureus.  Expanded coverage for Pseudomonas (eg, cefepime) should be used if the patient has a history of recent antibiotic use.  Antibiotics are tailored to the specific pathogen after susceptibility results are confirmed.  Patients initially receive intravenous antibiotics, followed by transition to oral therapy for approximately 4 weeks.



Drainage of the purulent material is also required.  This can be achieved by myringotomy (eg, middle ear drainage) with or without ear tube placement or mastoidectomy (

figure 4
).  Patients should be monitored to ensure that they do not develop more severe complications due to extracranial (eg, subperiosteal abscess, hearing loss) or intracranial (eg, meningitis, brain abscess) extension.

Complications



Patients can have extracranial complications, including:



  • Subperiosteal abscess, the most common complication.
  • Labyrinthitis due to the spread of infection to the bony labyrinth of the inner ear.
  • Facial nerve palsy due to infection or compression of the nerve as it travels through the temporal bone.
  • Hearing loss due to damage to the middle ear ossicles or cochlea.


Intracranial extension (eg, epidural space, meninges, brain) can also occur, causing meningitis, an epidural abscess, lateral sinus thrombosis, or a brain abscess.  Patients typically have signs of meningeal irritation (eg, neck stiffness and pain), focal neurologic deficits, and/or increased intracranial pressure (eg, vomiting).

Prognosis



Most cases resolve without long-term sequelae when treated promptly with antibiotics and, if necessary, surgical intervention.  Delayed treatment increases the risk of complications, particularly intracranial spread, which carries significant morbidity.

Summary



Mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid air cells, usually resulting from a complication of acute otitis media (
